answers.author: Sheri Campbell-Husband
answers.text:
I certainly understand the frustration several have expressed here on this topic.  I expressed it for several years myself.  What I had to learn was that most people are not going to come out of an MPA program and go directly into a job as a manager/assistant manager, unless they also have prior applicable real-world experience.  What I know NOW is that there are good reasons for that.  When I had been in the public management sector for 8 years, I finally realized the advice I'd gotten for years was right...the best way for me to get the budgetary and supervisory experience necessary to become ready for city management was to take a position as the director of a municipal service department.  In the time I held that job, I developed the skills and knowledge I once THOUGHT I already had.  Then, when the administrator position I now hold came along, I could truthfully tell the hiring Council that I had both the academic and experiential background they were seeking in an administrator.  
   I will also advise that, if you are unwilling/unable to put in a few years in a mid-management position to gain that experience, and being a manager TODAY is the only route you'll accept, you have to be willing to seek jobs in smaller, probably more rural areas where the salaries may not be as high.  You'll get GREAT experience quickly, and that's the trade-off for the difference in compensation. As a current participant in the Emerging Leaders Program, I encourage your participation in that as well.

answers.author: SheaBrianna Scharding
answers.text:
Although many jobs ask for 2-3 years experience, if you have strong internship or other work experience, they will often allow for it to substitute.  For example, my first job asked for 2-3 years experience (assistant manager) and I had a year at a strong internship where I could easily demonstrate that I could handle the responsibilities.  My current job (Township Manager) asked for 5-7 years, but my 3 years of strong experience as an Assistant Manager qualified me.  
My advice is to go above and beyond in your internship or other work experience and try to amass the skills you know you will need on the job.  Develop a portfolio of your work and prove that you are up to the job.  Then, research the job well- call and ask if they would consider someone with high quality experience gained in a shorter time span.  It also helps if you're willing to work for less.  Be creative in how you're marketing yourself. 
I also got involved in the Next Generation initiatives through ICMA- both the LGMF program and the Emerging Leaders program- which have been excellent ways to show prospective employers that I'm qualified and capable.

answers.author: Dustin Anderson
answers.text:
Even in a small community, as a manager you are basically the Chief Administrative Officer for a multi-million dollar concern. The responsibility is arguably greater in local government management than in the private sector because there is a public trust in your effective stewardship of their recourses. 
While there are many conversations to be had about the effectiveness and deployment of the NextGen initiative - and its proposed impact on the MPA graduates that are sitting on a ton of student loan debt - the availability of City Manager jobs for recent graduates probably would not be one of them.

answers.author: John Garvison
answers.text:
That is an excellent question and one I have been wondering about myself. I have heard so much about the next generation initiative, but have not seen much of this in practice, especially when all the job descriptions are asking for previous City Manager or City Administrator experience. I understand wanting previous experience in a job description, but am wondering how those of us in the next generation are going to in fact become City Manager's or City Administrator's with all of these requirements in place.
Are the City Manager's and City Administrator's that are leaving these smaller jurisdictions suggesting to their hiring committee's to hire the next generation? Or are other things occurring?
I know the job market is really bad right now, but I think this is an issue that needs to be answered, or else we won't have new blood coming into the ranks of the ICMA and covered positions.

answers.author: Kyle Ten Broeke
answers.text:
From my own experience, many village/city/township councils aren't "on board" with next generation initiatives.  In this economy they can get quite a bang for their buck rather than help develop an aspiring career manager.  I have been bested in several positions by crossovers from the private sector who were laid off or retired -- the council being left starry-eyed by their decades of experience and lack of need to provide benefits (at least to the retired).   This is horrible for the future of municipal management, but I don't know that the elected officials responsible for hiring know or care (the old "let someone else do it, we want the best for ourselves") what the future may look like if they don't hire next generation managers, providing us experience, now.
As for me, I have given up the search for a manager position and have instead taken an analyst position with the state.  I'll re-evaluate in a few years but in the meantime it's some meaningful work, relevant experience, and network-building.

answers.author: Jerry Andree
answers.text:
You must be patient and be willing to build a strong foundation in local government. Look for entry level positions within local government in areas that may interest you. Start with assistant to the manager, or assistant manager.  By investing a few years you will become a much more creditable candidate for municipal manager.

answers.author: Brian Wolverton
answers.text:
All very good answers... for me I chose to start with analyst positions so, when I'm learning the ropes, I don't have to do it the hard way in the context of a position of leadership where there's a lot at stake.  But if you're confident that management is something you're ready for, I'd also recommend involvement in local Board and Commissions (especially if you live a ways away from where you work, like I do).  My experience as Chairman of a city housing authority gave me executive-level experience in things like contract negotiation, labor relations, policy-making, and especially dealing with the public and the press, that I otherwise would not have had.

answers.author: Robert Carty
answers.text:
This question and answer were also posted on ICMA's Facebook page that picked up this question from the RSS feed:
David Marquez: How do you get experience without an internship since many cities are eliminating them? I have my MPA but get overlooked because I have no experience. Any ideas?
July 23 at 6:06pm
ICMA - International City/County Management Association: There are some good answers on the Knowledge Network site to help answer this question. But one thing not being eliminated are unpaid internships. I know that's an unacceptable answer, especially after accumulating a mountain of graduate school debt. Other options include pitching your assistance for short-term or one-off consulting projects. You might also approach the manager to see if you can put together a package that includes third-party funding to cover a special program (think federal, state or regional grants). In some cases a local government can bring some money to the table, but not enough for a full-time position. Yet another option is a shared internship - 50/50 with another community.
